    • Method Detail

      • fcn

        public void fcn(double[][] x,
                double[] p,
                double[] y)
        A normalized, 2D, symmetrical or elliptical, Gaussian point-spread function (PSF). This function can model multiple overlapping PSFs by using the appropriate p array.
        Specified by:
        fcn in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - a 2 by N list of x,y pixel coordinates, e.g. [ [x1, x2, ..., xN], [y1, y2, ..., yN] ]
        y - - the list containing the function values to be evaluated using the values in p for each value in x
        p - - the values of the function parameters
        • p[0] = background signal
        • p[1] = the localization in the x dimension
        • p[2] = the localization in the y dimension
        • p[3] = the total intensity (area under the curve) (the background signal is already subtracted)
        • p[4] = rotation angle, in radians, between the fluorescing molecule and the image canvas
        • p[5] = sigma of the 2D Gaussian in the x-dimension, sigmaX
        • p[6] = aspect ratio, sigmaY/sigmaX (or equivalently fwhmY/fwhmX)

        You can use p[5] and p[6] to model a symmetrical or elliptical Gaussian point-spread function in different ways.
        (see: LevMarBev for a description of pFloat[] below, that is of course, only if you are using the LevMarBev algorithm)

        (fixed-symmetrical) To force sigmaX=sigmaY=sigma and keep the value of sigma constant during the fit:
        set p[5]=sigma, p[6]=1.0, pFloat[5]=0, pFloat[6]=0

        (float-symmetrical) To force sigmaX=sigmaY=sigma and let the fit determine the best value for sigma:
        set p[5]=sigma, p[6]=1.0, pFloat[5]=1, pFloat[6]=0

        (fixed-fixed-elliptical) To force the values of sigmaX and sigmaY to be a constant during the fit:
        set p[5]=sigmaX, p[6]=aspect_ratio, pFloat[5]=0, pFloat[6]=0

        (float-fixed-elliptical) To determine the best values for sigmaX from the fit and force sigmaY to be a constant during the fit:
        set p[5]=sigmaX, p[6]=aspect_ratio, pFloat[5]=1, pFloat[6]=0

        (fixed-float-elliptical) To determine the best values for sigmaY from the fit and force sigmaX to be a constant during the fit:
        set p[5]=sigmaX, p[6]=aspect_ratio, pFloat[5]=0, pFloat[6]=1, and then determine sigmaY=p[5]*p[6] when the fitting routine is done

        (float-float-elliptical) To determine the best values for sigmaX and sigmaY from the fit:
        set p[5]=sigmaX, p[6]=aspect_ratio, pFloat[5]=1, pFloat[6]=1, and then determine sigmaY=p[5]*p[6] when the fitting routine is done

        If modeling multiple overlapping 2D Gaussians, then p must have a very specific structure. For example, consider 3 overlapping Gaussian PSFs, let's called them A, B, C. Then p must have the following structure:

        p = [
               background,
               A_x, A_y, A_intensity, A_angle, A_sigmaX, A_aspect,
               B_x, B_y, B_intensity, B_angle, B_sigmaX, B_aspect,
               C_x, C_y, C_intensity, C_angle, C_sigmaX, C_aspect
               ]

      • deriv

        public void deriv(double[][] x,
                  double[] p,
                  double[][] der)
        The partial derivatives (i.e. the derivatives with respect to each parameter). Used the CodeGeneration[Fortran] package from Maplesoft to generate this 'optimized' code. 'Optimized' in the sense that it tries to reduce the number of times that a calculation needs to be performed by storing the calculation in a temporary number and using this number for future calculations.
        Specified by:
        deriv in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - a 2 by N list of x,y pixel coordinates, e.g. [ [x1, x2, ..., xN], [y1, y2, ..., yN] ]
        p - - an array of the function parameters
        der - - a (p.length) x (x[0].length) array of the partial derivative values for each parameter

      • finalCheck

        public void finalCheck(double[][] x,
                       double[] y,
                       double[] p)
        Description copied from interface: FitFunction
        Final check (for nD data) to ensure that the best-guess parameters from the fit make sense or if you want to force a parameter to be within a certain range (e.g., if one of the fitting parameters is an angle and its final best-guess value is not between -π and π you can correct for its value to be within this range by adding/subtracting 2πn).

        You can specify code in this method to modify the values in p. If you don't want to modify p in any way or if your data set has dimension = 1 then you can just ignore this method.
        Specified by:
        finalCheck in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - the x values (the independent variable)
        y - - the y values (the dependent variable)
        p - - the values of the function parameters.

      • pCheck

        public void pCheck(double[] p,
                   double[] pInitial)
        Description copied from interface: FitFunction
        Checks to ensure that none of the fit parameters get an unrealistic (unwanted) value. If a parameter value does start to converge to an unrealistic (unwanted) value then it can either be set back to its initial-guess value or modified in another way (e.g., if one of the fitting parameters is the amplitude of a cosine function and you want its value to always be positive so that you don't have to worry about applying π phase shifts to compensate for a negative amplitude)
        Specified by:
        pCheck in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        p - - the current values of the function parameters. You can specify code in this method to replace unrealistic(unwanted) values by the appropriate values specified by you. If you don't want to modify p in any way then you can just ignore this method.
        pInitial - - the initial guess of the parameters

      • fcn

        public void fcn(double[] x,
                double[] p,
                double[] y)
        Not used since the x values are 2D
        Specified by:
        fcn in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - the x values (the independent variable)
        p - - the values of the function parameters
        y - - a list that is holding the y values (the value of the function evaluated at each x value). Does an in-place replacement of the value in y evaluated at each x value in order to avoid creating a new double[] y array on every method call from the fitting routine.

      • deriv

        public void deriv(double[] x,
                  double[] p,
                  double[][] der)
        Not used since the x values are 2D
        Specified by:
        deriv in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - the x values (the independent variable)
        p - - the values of the function parameters
        der - - a p.length by y.length array that is holding the values of the partial derivatives for each parameter that is evaluated at each x value. Does an in-place replacement of the value in der evaluated for each parameter and at each x value in order to avoid creating a new double[][] der array on every method call from the fitting routine.

      • finalCheck

        public void finalCheck(double[] x,
                       double[] y,
                       double[] p)
        Not used since the x values are 2D
        Specified by:
        finalCheck in interface FitFunction
        Parameters:
        x - - the x values (the independent variable)
        y - - the y values (the dependent variable)
        p - - the values of the function parameters.
